div.p: Greetings. Although I greatly wished to visit you, I was prevented by the harshness of the fever and partly by the weather; however, the fever, by the grace of God, was driven away by fasting. I received letters from Geneva and part of my book, which I am not sending because you will return to us within a day or two. I am sending you and yours a small gift, which I ask you to kindly accept; for you know this: in gifts, the intention is the best part. I am completely unaware of what is truly happening; for in these 15 days, I have never left the house. I hope to be in better health henceforth, since I have been freed from the fever. The rest we will discuss in person. Greet everyone; I pray for good health for you all.
The boy announced his departure only when he was already prepared for the journey. My family sends their regards to you.
My son sends you a letter that could make even the dead laugh; it would be the best medicine for the melancholic.
To the most excellent man in piety and learning, Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, my esteemed father.
